conclusion: State A is at a pressure of 3 x 10^5 Pa and a volume of 1 x 10^-3 m^3. State B is at a pressure of 1 x 10^5 Pa and a volume of 1 x 10^-3 m^3.
The ideal gas law is given by PV = nRT.
At state B, P_B = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 1 x 10^-3 m^3.

Since the volume remains constant, the number of moles (n) and the gas constant (R) are also constant. We can set up a ratio of the pressures and temperatures at states A and B: P_A / T_A = P_B / T_B.
Substitute the known values: (3 x 10^5 Pa) / 300.15 K = (1 x 10^5 Pa) / T_B.
Cross-multiply and solve for T_B: T_B = (3 x 10^5 Pa) * (300.15 K) / (1 x 10^5 Pa).
Convert the temperature from Kelvin to Celsius: T_B (in °C) = T_B (in K) - 273.15.
The temperature of the gas at state B is 627.3°C.
